channel.title: Opinion : NPR
channel.description: Editorial opinions and commentary on news events and world events. Download podcasts and subscribe to RSS feeds.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Newborn Baby Abandoned In Church's Manger Already Being Loved
item.description: This week, the love of a mother who felt she couldn't care for her child led her to bring him some place safe and warm. And he was found by people who will—who already do—love him.
item.content:encoded: This week, the love of a mother who felt she couldn't care for her child led her to bring him some place safe and warm. And he was found by people who will—who already do—love him.
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: Dear Pope Francis, As You Visit Uganda, Here's What You Should Know
item.description: The pope arrives in the country on Friday. Commentators James Kassaga Arinaitwe and Viviane Rutabingwa give him a crash course in the country's issues.
item.content:encoded: The pope arrives in the country on Friday. Commentators James Kassaga Arinaitwe and Viviane Rutabingwa give him a crash course in the country's issues.
item.dc:creator: James Kassaga Arinaitwe

item.title: There Are No Winners Without Losers
item.description: Somebody has to lose, right? So, let's learn from defeat.
item.content:encoded: Somebody has to lose, right? So, let's learn from defeat.
item.dc:creator: Frank Deford

item.title: Green Bean Casserole: The Thanksgiving Staple We Love — Or Loathe
item.description: The classic Midwestern casserole, which turns 60 this year, has come to mean more than just a mashup of processed food. Even those who grew up with it but can't abide it admit: It tastes like home.
item.content:encoded: The classic Midwestern casserole, which turns 60 this year, has come to mean more than just a mashup of processed food. Even those who grew up with it but can't abide it admit: It tastes like home.
item.dc:creator: Peggy Lowe

item.title: Going Live (Or Not): NPR's Complicated Approach To Breaking News
item.description: When news breaks, how NPR responds depends on more than just good news judgment.
item.content:encoded: When news breaks, how NPR responds depends on more than just good news judgment.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Jensen

item.title: The Long Saga Of Spy Jonathan Pollard Continues Even After His Release
item.description: He's on parole for another five years, during which he'll have to wear a GPS ankle bracelet, won't be able to give interviews, or leave for Israel. NPR's Scott Simon reflects on his release.
item.content:encoded: He's on parole for another five years, during which he'll have to wear a GPS ankle bracelet, won't be able to give interviews, or leave for Israel. NPR's Scott Simon reflects on his release.
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: Islamic State, ISIS, ISIL or Daesh?
item.description: Listeners weigh in on what we should call the terrorist group responsible for the Paris attacks.
item.content:encoded: Listeners weigh in on what we should call the terrorist group responsible for the Paris attacks.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Jensen

item.title: Commentary: Mizzou Football And The Power Of The Players
item.description: Frank Deford wonders: Once the games are over, are the football players really accepted, or are they just hired hands?
item.content:encoded: Frank Deford wonders: Once the games are over, are the football players really accepted, or are they just hired hands?
item.dc:creator: Frank Deford

item.title: Gray-Haired Granny? An 85-Year-Old Writer Goes Punk Rock Instead
item.description: When novelist Anne Bernays became a great-grandmother, she dyed her hair bright blue. She says young people tend to treat the elderly as if they're dumb, "whereas I feel like I'm still a teenager."
item.content:encoded: When novelist Anne Bernays became a great-grandmother, she dyed her hair bright blue. She says young people tend to treat the elderly as if they're dumb, "whereas I feel like I'm still a teenager."
item.dc:creator: Anne Bernays

item.title: 'Heds' Will Roll: Readers React To Headlines Gone Wrong
item.description: As some listeners raise concerns, a new digital strategy already in the works will give headlines a little more TLC.
item.content:encoded: As some listeners raise concerns, a new digital strategy already in the works will give headlines a little more TLC.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Jensen

item.title: The NFL Is Kicking The Ball To The United Kingdom. Why?
item.description: London soon will be hosting up to eight NFL games each fall. What's behind these plans to play so many regular season games across the pond?
item.content:encoded: London soon will be hosting up to eight NFL games each fall. What's behind these plans to play so many regular season games across the pond?
item.dc:creator: Frank Deford

item.title: Analysis: At The University Of Missouri, An Unlearned Free Speech Lesson
item.description: When student protesters confronted journalists, some faculty members seemed to forget about the First Amendment, NPR's David Folkenflik says.
item.content:encoded: When student protesters confronted journalists, some faculty members seemed to forget about the First Amendment, NPR's David Folkenflik says.
item.dc:creator: David Folkenflik

item.title: Bill Belichick: Love Him, Hate Him, But Don't Deny He's An Original
item.description: The time has come to recognize that Bill Belichick is the best pro-sports coach of this century, says commentator Frank Deford.
item.content:encoded: The time has come to recognize that Bill Belichick is the best pro-sports coach of this century, says commentator Frank Deford.
item.dc:creator: Frank Deford

item.title: A Missing Report On Exxon Mobil And Climate Change
item.description: Listeners question why NPR ignored a story widely reported elsewhere.
item.content:encoded: Listeners question why NPR ignored a story widely reported elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Jensen

item.title: Plagiarism Found In 10 NPR Music Stories
item.description: The author of the 10 stories, who was based at New York's WQXR, has resigned.
item.content:encoded: The author of the 10 stories, who was based at New York's WQXR, has resigned.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Jensen
